image.altText: A composite image of murder victims Luke Davies (left) and Jesse Baird

props.synopsis: NSW Police say two bodies have been found on a rural property near Goulburn as part of an investigation into the murder of Sydney couple Luke Davies and Jesse Baird.

title.children: Police find two bodies as part of investigation into alleged murder of Sydney couple

image.altText: A CFS firefighter stands next to a koala.

props.synopsis: Fire authorities have urged South Australians in seven districts to prepare for possible bushfires on Wednesday ahead of "extreme" conditions.

title.children: Aerial firefighting units on standby as South Australia prepares for 'extreme' fire danger

image.altText: Four police officers stand under an awning attached to a police car, parked on a suburban street

props.synopsis: A 23-year-old man has died after allegedly being stabbed at his home in Adelaide's north this morning. Police say a 27-year-old man has been arrested and charged with murder.

title.children: Man charged with murder after young man dies from alleged stabbing in Adelaide's north

image.altText: Firefighters using foam to put out a car fire on a dead end street as a police office looks on

props.synopsis: A man has been charged with arson after a car was found destroyed at Kurralta Park in Adelaide's south-west on Monday. Officers are investigating whether the car is linked to a shooting at Wayville.

title.children: Police charge man with arson over car fire in Adelaide, investigating links to shooting

image.altText: Female legal

props.synopsis: Three years after revelations of widespread sexual harassment and bullying rocked South Australia's legal profession, a review is underway to examine the effectiveness of the industry's response.

title.children: Sexual harassment complaints in legal profession at risk of hitting bureaucratic 'curtain', Chief Justice warns

image.altText: Smoke and an orange glow from a fire burning in the Cherry Gardens area of the Adelaide Hills.

props.synopsis: A former Country Fire Service volunteer who deliberately lit fires in the Adelaide Hills three years ago has been condemned in court by the agency's current chief, who said the firebug's actions put the communities at risk of an "Ash Wednesday-type" disaster and had tarnished the reputation of the entire CFS.

title.children: CFS chief blasts former volunteer over deliberately-lit Adelaide Hills bushfire

image.altText: A close portrait of a woman in business attire, who is looking at the camera with a neutral expression.

props.synopsis: NDIS Quality and Safeguards Commissioner Tracey Mackey announces she will "embark on new career opportunities" just two days before an independent report investigating a scandal exposed by Four Corners is due.

title.children: NDIS commissioner resigns days before report due into scandal exposed by Four Corners

image.altText: Two officers hold a banner saying Australian Federal Police in the Mardi Gras parade

props.synopsis: An AFP spokesperson says they will not march in the Sydney Gay and Lesbian Mardi Gras this year, following the alleged murders of Jesse Baird and Luke Davies.

title.children: 'We understand their hurt': Australian Federal Police decide not to march at Mardi Gras

image.altText: Prince William looking concerned

props.synopsis: Prince William has pulled out of attending a memorial service at Windsor Castle for his godfather, the late King Constantine of Greece, because of an unspecified personal matter, his office said.

title.children: Prince William pulls out of memorial service for late godfather, citing 'personal matter'

image.altText: Morrison's back faces the camera as he walks through a doorway.

props.synopsis: Delivering his final speech to parliament, the former prime minister warns threats to Australia's sovereignty remain real, and Australia should not be fooled by Beijing's tactics.

title.children: Scott Morrison makes warning on China in departing speech to parliament

image.altText: Albanese looks up while standing at a lectern, an Australian flag behind him.

props.synopsis: The government's overhaul of the stage 3 tax cuts passed the Senate unamended on Tuesday evening, having previously passed in the House of Representatives. The tax cuts will now become law.

title.children: Government's overhaul of stage 3 tax cuts pass Senate

image.altText: A woman walks along the footpath of an empty street in front of construction sites for residential buildings in the Kangbashi district of the town of Ordos in China's Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region

props.synopsis: After China's property market implosion, there are growing fears its banking and financial system may be impacted too. It's further proof that China's economy is unravelling at a pace previously thought unimaginable, writes Ian Verrender.

title.children: China's economy is unravelling at a pace previously thought unimaginable. Where does that leave Australia?

image.altText: A tree's root system is on display in front of a brick wall, surrounded by metal signs and a small information centre.

props.synopsis: In Australian lore, anywhere "beyond the black stump" is usually inhospitable country. But in this South Australian town, a centuries-old river red gum "black stump" has been attracting tourists for decades.

title.children: How a six-tonne 'black stump' has become a small town's biggest tourist attraction

image.altText: A lady in a purple dress with a purple dress standing in front of a disabled park with her walking stick

props.synopsis: People living with disabilities in regional South Australia are moving to the state's capital due to a lack of accessible infrastructure and services.

title.children: Why people living with disabilities are considering moving away from regional areas

image.altText: close up of a barista's hands making coffee into an aqua coloured mug

props.synopsis: Last year Labor passed legislation to criminalise wage theft, but its legislation did not fulfil part of its promise, according to experts.

title.children: Labor's promise to criminalise wage theft without overriding state laws is stalled. Here's why

image.altText: Former rugby league great Wally Lewis smiles for the cameras as he holds an orange t-shirt tagged "you only get one brain".

props.synopsis: Rugby league great Wally Lewis goes to Canberra to meet politicians, share his experiences of short-term memory loss and call for federal money to be put towards education and support for the fight against chronic traumatic encephalopathy (CTE).

title.children: 'My diary ... is my best friend': League great Wally Lewis urges politicians to put CTE funding in budget

image.altText: A woman holds up a pink dress and looks at it thoughtfully in a clothing store.

props.synopsis: How can brands that market to women, sell to women, exist on the goodwill and support of women, pay them so much less than men, asks Daniel Ziffer.

title.children: The companies that take lots of money from women, but don't give so much back

image.altText: Graphic of different company logos as squares with a graph in the middle

props.synopsis: The gender pay gap — the difference between what men and women are paid in the same organisation — is a stubborn problem. Now, explosive new data from a government agency lets 5 million workers know the gap at their employer.

title.children: Gender pay shock as big gaps revealed in what men and women earn at nation's biggest companies

image.altText: Write Maggie Zhou and Jessie Wright at a restaurant meeting for dinner as part of Jessie's weekly meals with strangers.

props.synopsis: Going on a platonic date didn't feel too dissimilar to a romantic one. You dress up, feel nervous, and store comfortable conversation topics in your back pocket.

title.children: Why a friendship date with a stranger worked for me

image.altText: Fred Again performing at Laneway Festival hunched over DJ decks with red lighting behind him

props.synopsis: It's happening. Fred again.. is in Australia (again) and is playing a surprise show (again). Here's how we figured it out before he confirmed it.

title.children: Here's how we figured out Fred Again.. was coming to Australia

image.altText: An illustration of a person looking sad in a group in front of a rainbow background

props.synopsis: LGBTQ+ Australians are experiencing mental illness and self harm at rates sometimes "more than double" their heterosexual counterparts, new data released by the Australian Bureau of Statistics reveals.

title.children: 'Discrimination, assault and harassment': New data paints a 'sobering' picture of mental health for LGBTQ+ Australians

image.altText: A winding metal slide twists through lush Australian bushland.

props.synopsis: The unique sinkhole in Tasmania's remote north-west was meant to be a much-needed tourism drawcard for the area. Instead, the site has fallen into disrepair, leaving locals shocked at its condition.

title.children: It was to be a tourism drawcard, but it's been 'left to rot' — and locals want to know why

subjects.title: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Art

image.altText: A person watches a large bushfire burning in the distance.

props.synopsis: The second of two bushfires which threatened lives and homes in South Bunbury and Australind on Tuesday is brought under control with the threat from both fires now downgraded.

title.children: Firefighters bring blaze threatening lives, homes in South Bunbury under control

props.synopsis: A Gold Coast magistrate has ordered Eddie Hayson's extradition to Sydney, where he will face court later this week.

title.children: Punter and former brothel owner Eddie Hayson arrested after drug syndicate probe

image.altText: A woman with blonde hair looks to the side, as a man in a suit stares ahead.

props.synopsis: WA Liberal Leader Libby Mettam dismisses her deputy leader Steve Thomas after it emerges he used disgraced former premier Brian Burke as a middleman to secure a meeting.

title.children: WA Liberal leader sacks her deputy for enlisting help of disgraced former premier and denying it

image.altText: A close up photo taken by a lunar lander near the surface of the Moon

props.synopsis: A private US Moon lander is expected to stop working days before originally planned, while a Japanese one is again showing signs of life.

title.children: US Moon lander mission cut short after landing sideways as Japan's lander survives another lunar night

image.altText: A Queensland paramedic stands at the back of an ambulance.

props.synopsis: Dozens of Queensland Police Service and Queensland Ambulance Service staff challenged their workplace mandates in the Supreme Court in 2022, after they refused to comply with the directives.

title.children: Mandating COVID-19 vaccines for some Queensland frontline workers was unlawful, judge rules

image.altText: A tree hangs over a deserted stretch of beach.

props.synopsis: Police are urging anyone who may recognise the belongings to come forward.

title.children: Police share photos of woman's posessions after body found on popular Gold Coast beach

image.altText: A mug shot of a bald man in his twenties

props.synopsis: Joshua Duperouzel is sentenced to life in prison after he shot dead a man at a semi-rural property in Perth because believed he owed a $3,000 debt.

title.children: Man given life sentence after shooting dead another man over alleged $3,000 drug debt

image.altText: A line of police officers walk down the side of a street looking down at the ground.

props.synopsis: A man is dead after a drive-by shooting in south-west Sydney during the morning rush hour in what police called a targeted attack.

title.children: Man killed in drive-by shooting in south-west Sydney during morning rush hour

image.altText: A school photo of a teacher in a school photo with young students. The kids faces are blurred

props.synopsis: After six months examining decades of crimes against students in state-run schools, the government-initiated inquiry leading the investigation delivers its findings to the Victorian governor.

title.children: In the early 70s, four paedophiles taught together at this school. Survivors say it was a sign of an insidious crisis

image.altText: A man holds a finger up to a woman holding a thong over her head. Cameras are around them.

props.synopsis: Zachary Rolfe apologises for his use of racial slurs in text exchanges with colleagues as he gives evidence for a second day after his lawyers called for members of the public who allegedly threatened him outside court to be arrested.

title.children: Rolfe rejects allegations of racism, perjury, violence in tense day of evidence at Walker inquest

image.altText: Police officer looks away from camera at a press conference

props.synopsis: Commissioner Michael Murphy has confirmed inquires will be undertaken into explosive racism claims made by former constable Zachary Rolfe at the Kumanjayi Walker coronial inquest.

title.children: NT Police entrenched racism claims investigated as identity of high-ranking officers suppressed

image.altText: Xi Jinping raises his glass and proposes a toast while standing behind a lecturn in front of Chinese flags.

props.synopsis: The ABC understands that China is on track to lift wine tariffs it had placed on Australian at the end of March, after Trade Minister Don Farrell met with his Chinese counterpart Wang Wentao overnight.

title.children: China wine tariffs expected to be gone by end of March after trade minister meets with Chinese counterpart

image.altText: The front of a Coles supermarket. Underneath a large sign are displays of fruit and vegetables.

props.synopsis: Shares in Coles have surged despite its profit falling in the six months to December when its supermarket revenue was rising. Here's how the trading day unfolded.

title.children: Coles shares surge despite half-year profit falling as supermarket revenue rose, Bitcoin soars 8pc in one day — as it happened
